conclusion: The problem involves an ideal gas transitioning through states A, B, and C on a p-V diagram. The temperature at state A is given as 27°C.
From the p-V diagram, at state A, the pressure \( p_A = 3 \times 10^5 \, \text{Pa} \) and volume \( V_A = 1 \times 10^{-3} \, \text{m}^3 \).
From the p-V diagram, at state B, the pressure \( p_B = 1 \times 10^5 \, \text{Pa} \) and volume \( V_B = 1 \times 10^{-3} \, \text{m}^3 \).
The ideal gas law is given by \( pV = nRT \), where \( p \) is pressure, \( V \) is volume, \( n \) is the number of moles, \( R \) is the gas constant, and \( T \) is temperature.

premise: From the ideal gas law, \( \frac{p_A V_A}{T_A} = \frac{p_B V_B}{T_B} \).
conclusion: The temperature at state B can be calculated using \( T_B = \frac{p_B V_B T_A}{p_A V_A} \).
Substituting into \( T_B = \frac{p_B V_B T_A}{p_A V_A} \), we get \( T_B = \frac{(1 \times 10^5)(1 \times 10^{-3})(300)}{(3 \times 10^5)(1 \times 10^{-3})} = 100 \, \text{K} \).

premise: The calculated temperature at state B is \( T_B = 100 \, \text{K} \).
conclusion: The temperature of the gas at state B is 100 K.
